title: Solar Energy in India
summary: How photovoltaic cells convert sunlight to electricity — and why India is a solar superpower.
content:
Case Study: Solar Energy in India

India receives an average of 300 sunny days per year. The government's National Solar Mission aims for 500 GW of solar capacity by 2030. Let's understand the physics.

The Photoelectric Effect

Einstein's 1905 discovery: photons of light knock electrons out of a material. A solar cell (photovoltaic cell) uses this effect — photons from sunlight free electrons in silicon, creating an electric current.

Energy Conversion Chain

  1. Solar radiation (electromagnetic energy) hits the silicon panel
  2. Photoelectric effect creates DC electricity
  3. Inverter converts DC to AC for household use
  4. Excess energy can charge an inverter battery for night-time use

Efficiency

Commercial solar panels convert about 15–22% of sunlight into electricity. The rest is reflected or converted to heat. Research into perovskite cells aims to push efficiency beyond 30%.

India's Numbers

A 1 kW rooftop solar system in Rajasthan generates about 5–6 units (kWh) per day. At ₹8 per unit, this saves ₹40–48 per day — roughly ₹15,000 per year!
